metadata.title: High-performance competence of polyaniline-based nanomaterials

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 2 March 2019 Accepted 17 April 2019
KEYWORDS Polyaniline; conjugation; nanomaterial; anticorrosion; solar cell

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The conjugated polymer-based one-dimensional nanofibre material possesses significant characteristics, such as high mechanical strength, thermal stability, flexibility, electrical conductivity, and biocompatibility [1,2]. The conjugated polymers own intrinsic conductivity of 10−5 to 10−3 Scm−1. However, the conductivity property may be improved to semiconductor level via chemical modification. Polyaniline (PANI) is a widely reconnoitred polymer owing to facile synthesis, thermal resistance, environmental stability, and fine optical and magnetic properties [3–5]. PANI nanomaterials include zero-dimensional (nanoparticle), one-dimensional (nanowire), two-dimensional (film), and threedimensional structures (polycrystal). Consequently, PANI has been produced in several one-dimensional nanostructural forms such as rod, tube, fibre, etc. Various routes have been used to produce one-dimensional PANI nanomaterial such as electrospinning, lithography, templating, and several physical and chemical methods. The success of methods lies in control of size, morphology, uniformity, and oriented nanostructure arrays of nanofibre. Mass production of nanofibre at low cost and facile process for large scale production is also crucial. Electrospun PANI-based nanocomposite nanofibres have been used as important materials for rapidly growing technologies. PANI has been employed in various technical applications such as sensors, batteries, electrochromic devices, fuel cell, and electromagnetic interference shielding materials. Conductivity properties of PANI fibre and composite fibre have been studied [6–8]. PANI-based composite fibres have found applications in membrane application, energy devices, and biomedical
CONTACT Ayesha Kausar dr.ayeshakausar@yahoo.com National University of Sciences and Technology, Islamabad, Pakistan
© 2019 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group
relevance [9,10]. In this review, various essential aspects of PANI-based nanomaterial have been unveiled. Research has shown the potential of PANI-based nanomaterial in various fields such as membrane, anticorrosion, solar cell, supercapacitor, sensor, and biomedical. However, there are several challenges need to be overcome in the fabrication and use of these nanomaterial for future applications.

sections.heading: 2. Polyaniline
sections.text:
Conducting polymers have gained success in the fields of film, coatings, membranes, and nanoelectrodes [11]. Several conducting polymers have been used to cast one-dimensional nanostructure (ID) such as polypyrrole, polythiophene, poly (p-phenylenevinylene), and poly(3,4-ethylene dioxythiophene) and their derivatives [12]. PANI is an important type of conducting polymer. It is one of the eldest synthetic conducting polymers having high intrinsic electrical conductivity. PANI can be polymerised from inexpensive aniline monomer. PANI can be found in different oxidation states such as emeraldine, pernigraniline, and leucoemeraldine. The colour change of PANI is associated with its different oxidation states. As a consequence, PANI has facile synthesis, high stability, and controllable electrical conductivity through variable protonation or oxidation state [13,14]. Electrical properties of PANI have been varied by changing the protonation of imine nitrogen and oxidation state of the main chain. PANI has been synthesised as ID nanostructure such as nanotube, nanofibre, and nanowire. PANI-based nanofibre has been developed to enhance the use of this important conducting polymer. In nanofibre form, electrical conductivity of PANI has been enhanced to 102–105 Scm−1. Moreover, processability, manageable chemical feature, electrochemical properties, doping/dedoping, conduction mechanism, and electrical properties of PANI nanofibres are exceptional, compared with the neat polymer [15,16]. PANI nanofibre also has large surface area, water processability, and acid–base sensitivity. Consequently, PANI nanofibre has established much consideration due to superior properties compared with the conventional PANI or PANI film [9,17,18]. Research on PANI
nanofibre has led to potential applications in sensors and actuators, rechargeable batteries, electric devices, electromagnetic shielding devices, and anticorrosion coatings [19–22]. Subsequently, electronic and physicochemical properties of PANI nanomaterial can be modified through amending polymer backbone structure, and nature and concentration of dopants.

sections.heading: 3. PANI-based nanomaterials
sections.text:
Conducting polymers have found applications in electronic, optical, magnetic, and biomedical fields [12]. PANI exists in various forms such as nanowire, nanorod, nanofibre, and nanotube [23–25]. The nanomaterials have been prepared using range of physical and chemical methods such as self-assembly, nanolithography, nanoporous template, electrospinning, and numerous chemical and physical methods [26]. Electrospun PANI nanofibre was prepared using solution of PANI, poly (vinyl butyral) (PVB), and poly(ethylene oxide) [27]. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to study the morphology of electrospun nanofibres (Figure 1). Smooth poly(styrene sulfonic acid) doped polyaniline (PANI-PSSA) nanofibres were obtained without any beads at various concentrations of PVB. Heat treatment was also used to maintain the nanofibre morphology. PANI nanomaterials have been synthesised using in situ chemical oxidative polymerisation method with urea as soft template [28]. In this method, aligned PANI fibres with nanometric diameter have been produced. Polymer solution is placed in a syringe connected to grounded collector. Strong electrostatic field is applied between needle and collector. In the presence of high electric field, jet is formed and moved towards collector accelerated by high voltage [29]. Hard and soft template methods have also been used for PANI nanofibre formation. Hard template method may employ aluminium oxide as template for nanofibre formation [30]. Soft template method may use emulsion,micelle, surfactant, liquid, and crystal to form PANI nanomaterials [31]. Self-assembly technique may involve micelle formation using dopant to form fibre [32,33]. In this way, various methods have been used to form PANI-based micro- or nanomaterials [34–37]. Among polymerisation
techniques, in situ, emulsion and interfacial techniques have been used [38]. Polymerisation techniques permit the formation of PANI nanofibre without using any template [39]. PANI nanofibres have been synthesised by interfacial polymerisation. Transmission electronmicroscopy (TEM) image of PANInanofibre is shown in Figure 2. The PANI nanofibre possesses large accessible surface area. Production of PANI-based nanocomposite nanofibre having narrow diameter, homogeneous surface, high conductivity, strength, and thermal stability is a great challenge for researchers. Multiple aspects of nanocomposite nanofibre have been explored for morphology development. Cross-section surface of pure PANI fibre shows even morphology (Figure 3(a)) [40]. In PANI/CNT composite fibre, some porosity was observed (Figure 3(b)). The PANI/CNT fibre has shown fracturemarks on cross-section.Developments related to PANI-based nanofibre processing, physical characteristics, conductivity, mechanical properties, thermal stability, and technical applications have been discussed in the following sections of this review. Few of the systems and parameters are listed in Table 1.

sections.heading: 4.1. Membrane application
sections.text:
PANI has been used in free-standing membranes and films for gas separation, pervaporation, and electrodialysis applications [41,42]. The undoped PANI membranes were found more permeable to gases, compared with the doped film. In doped films, removal of dopant may lead to void space in polymer. In PANI membranes, usually molecules larger than 4.5 Å are prohibited from permeation. Nagarale et al. [43] developed sulfonated cation-exchange membrane (CEM) and anionexchange membrane (AEM) of PANI. PANI nanocomposite ion-exchange membranes were studied for ion-exchange capacity, coating density, and membrane conductance. Coating densities are given in Figure 4. The coating density of CEM/ PANI was much higher than that of AEM/PANI. The effect was observed due to high extent of adsorption of anilinium species on negatively charged surface of CEM. Models for CEM/PANI and AEM/PANI composite membranes are given in Figure 5(a,b). The composite membranes own low hydrophilicity and reduced interaction with hydrated ions due to hydrophobic nature of PANI. Positively charged conducting state of PANI on CEM surface causes electrostatic repulsion between the protonated amine/imine group of PANI and multivalent cations. Surface charge density of AEM/PANI and CEM/PANI membranes was enhanced owing to charged nature of amine/imine group. Table 2 shows solute permeability coefficients for neat CEM, AEM, and PANI nanocomposite membranes. For Na+, CEM/PANI membrane had higher permeability than neat CEM. On the other hand, permeability of AEM was higher than AEM/PANI. Moreover, PANI nanocomposite membrane showed less permeability for bivalent counter ions compared with CEM or AEM. It was found that the chemical composition of membrane surface was varied with increase in polymerisation time. Chen et al. [44] studied PANI and silica-modified Nafion membranes. The aniline monomer was in situ polymerised to form PANI. The silica was embedded in Nafion matrix through polycondensation of tetraethylorthosilicate. The Nafion and Nafion/PANI nanofibrous membranes were studied for methanol/water uptake (Figure 6). Total uptake was increased to maximum at 75 vol.%, as methanol concentration was increased (water concentration decreased). On the other hand, at 25 vol.% methanol in water, total water uptake was 10%. Thus, the total uptake in membranes was very low for low methanol concentration. The Nafion and Nafion/PANI nanofibrous membranes were tested for proton conductivity at different temperatures (Figure 7). The PANI-modified membranes had low conductivities compared with pure Nafion. The low proton conductivity may be attributed to interaction between PANI and Nafion, thus interfering the proton transport mechanisms [45,46]. Tan et al. [47] also prepared nanofibrous membranes of PANI. The membrane showed optimal permselectivity for protons against bivalent metallic Zn2+ and Cu2+ cations. However, PANI nanofibres own high surface
area to interact with bivalent cations [48–50]. Consequently, ion-exchange capacity of membrane was decreased due to the presence of cations.

sections.heading: 4.2. Corrosion protection
sections.text:
Corrosion protection effect of conducting polymers especially PANI has been studied on iron metal [51,52]. However, application of PANI has been limited due to poor solubility, infusibility, and non-processable properties [53]. In order to improve anticorrosion property of PANI, nanocomposite structures have been researched. Nanocomposite coatings of PANI and epoxy have been studied for corrosion protection [54]. Better dispersion of PANI in epoxy enhanced the anticorrosion prospects of composite. Ge et al. [55] prepared composite coatings of PANI nanofibre and tested corrosion protective ability for Q235 steel. The PANI/epoxy resin was prepared bymechanical grinding. The anticorrosion effect was pronounced for 0.5 wt.% PANI. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used to study the corrosion effects.
Tiitu et al. [56] prepared PANI nanomaterials for corrosion prevention of steel and aluminium. PANI nanomaterial was added to diglycidyl ether of bisphenol-A (DGEBA) epoxy resin. Sufficiently homogeneous DGEBA/PANI coatings were obtained with 1 wt.% emeraldine. The nanocomposite coating was tested in aqueous 3.5% NaCl solution for corrosion suppression. EIS studies revealed fine corrosion protection due to the formation of an interface between DGEBA/ PANI and steel. It has become increasingly important to identify new PANI nanomaterials to develop multicomponent anticorrosion materials and coatings. Dispersion of PANI nanofibre and nanocomposite nanofibre may lead to highperformance anticorrosion coatings.

sections.heading: 4.3. Solar cell application
sections.text:
Dye-sensitised solar cell has been considered as an alternative to silicon-based solar cell owing to simple fabrication and versatile counter electrode [57,58]. Electrospun PANI nanocomposite has been focused for dye-sensitised solar cell [59].
Figure 3. Scanning electron micrographs of cross-section of (a) PANI and (b) PANI/CNT fibre at low and high magnification [40].
The materials may offer low fabrication cost, facile preparation technique, cell stability, and high performance compared with conventional solar cells. Wang et al. [60] prepared PANI/graphene nanocomposite nanofibre using in situ polymerisation of aniline in presence of graphene nanosheet. Figure 8 shows photocurrent–voltage curves of solar cell
with PANI/graphene nanocomposite, pure PANI, and Pt counter electrode. PANI nanoparticle on graphene nanosheet surface was found to enhance the conductivity and dispersion of nanoparticle. Table 3 shows photovoltaic parameters such as open-circuit voltage (Voc), short-circuit current density (Jsc), fill factor (FF), and conversion efficiency (η). PANI counter electrode had lower conversion efficiency of 4.78% and FF of 0.54. The PANI/graphene nanocomposite counter electrode revealed Voc of 0.685 V, Jsc of 13.28 mA cm−2, FF of 0.67, and η of 6.09%. The conversion efficiency was found comparable to that of Pt counter electrode (η = 6.88%). PANI/ graphene nanofibre was considered as effective material to fabricate counter solar cell electrode. Polylactic acid/PANI nanofibre with multi-walled carbon nanotube has been employed in dye-sensitised solar cell counter electrodes [61]. Future efforts may lead to simple, cost-efficient, conducting,
and flexible PANI nanofibre electrode for next generation solar cell [62].

sections.heading: 4.4. Use in supercapacitor and sensor
sections.text:
The supercapacitor materials based on conducting polymers possess high power density, high energy density, charge and discharge, and long life cycle [63]. PANI own high capacitance, chemical stability, and intrinsic redox states to be employed in supercapacitor electrodes [64]. PANI/polyacrylonitrile core-shell nanomaterial has been developed for supercapacitor electrode [65]. The specific capacitance of 267 Fg−1 and current density of 0.35Ag−1 were obtained for PANI nanofibre web, while neat PANI powder had specific capacitance of 208 Fg−1. Zhang et al. [66] prepared chemically modified graphene and PANI nanofibre nanocomposite using in situ polymerisation of aniline monomer with graphene oxide. Figure 9 shows in situ polymerisation of aniline in presence of graphene oxide to form nanofibre. The nanocomposite was treated with hydrazine to form conductive graphene nanosheet in nanofibre. The material was tested for supercapacitor electrode performance. The specific capacitance of 480 F/g at current density of 0.1 A/g was obtained. High specific capacitance and cycling stability was observed
in charge–discharge process for supercapacitor electrodes. Hence, high specific capacitance and cycling stability can be obtained using PANI nanocomposite nanofibre. PANI nanocomposite with nanocarbon nanoparticle can be explored for tuning and control of nanocomposite microstructure for high-performance electrode materials.
Sensors have been developed using PANI-based nanofibre materials [67]. PANI nanofibre has shown superior
performance, compared with the conventional materials. Virji et al. [68] prepared PANI nanofibre using interfacial polymerisation method. The nanofibres own high surface area, porosity, and small diameter for improved diffusion of molecules such as ammonia, HCl, etc. Huang et al. [69] used template-free chemical synthesis to produce uniform PANI nanofibre having diameter <100 nm. Resistive-type sensor of PANI nanofibre was tested for exposure to acid or base vapour. Chen et al. [70] prepared electrospun PANI nanofibre doped with palladium nanoparticle. The palladium nanoparticle-based chemiresistor had 1.8% resistance change in environment with 0.3% hydrogen concentration. The nanofibre sensor had fine flexibility, reversibility, and potential versatility. The gas sensors fabricated using PANI nanofibre have shown prospective application for detection of various gases.
Figure 8. Photocurrent density–voltage curves of solar cell with various counter electrodes [60].

sections.heading: 4.5. Biomedical relevance
sections.text: The application areas of PANI-based nanomaterials include tissue engineering, antibacterial agents, drug delivery, and other biomedical applications [71]. PANI has been applied as conductive substrates for tissue engineering. PANI nanofibre has been used to form scaffolds having large surface area, interconnected porous structure, biocompatible, and biodegradable structure [72]. In tissue engineering, PANI-based nanomaterials have been used to fabricate new tissues from cultured cells [73,74]. New biological implants have been designed to compete the collagen in biocompatibility and tensile strength [75,76]. Kim et al. [77] designed composite of PANI nanofibre in collagen matrix. The PANI nanofibre/ collagen composite had high electrical conductivity with PANI addition in the composite. Culturing of porcine skeletal muscle cells on composite films suggested success of the material for biomedical applications. Poyraz et al. [78] used silver nanoparticle-embedded PANI nanofibre as antibacterial agents. The nanocomposite was prepared through seeding polymerisation reaction via one-step redox/complexation process. The nanocomposite exhibited fine antibacterial affect against Gram-negative Escherichia coli and Gram-positive Staphylococcus aureus. Methodology advancement may lead to development of PANI/silver nanoparticle nanofibrillar network for advanced antibacterial agents. Pramanik et al. [79] designed hyperbranched poly(ester amide)/PANI nanofibremodified montmorillonite nanocomposite using ex-situ polymerisation technique. Antimicrobial activity of nanomaterial was tested against broad spectrum microbes such as bacteria, fungi, and algal consortium. The enhanced antimicrobial activity of nanocomposite against spectrum of bacterial and fungal strains depicted its potential in biomedical industry. Conducting polymers have also been used in drug delivery applications owing to reversible electrochemical response, i.e. contraction upon reduction and expansion on oxidation. This feature permits the controlled release of various kinds of drugs [80,81]. Electrospun PANI nanofibre offers high surface area and can be easily loaded with drug [82]. The drug release can be controlled by electrical stimulation. Electrospun PANI nanofibre has been used for controlled drug release [83]. Hence, PANI nanofibre and nanocomposite fibre have found enormous potential for tissue engineering, drug delivery, and antimicrobial applications.

sections.heading: 5. Challenges, future, and summary
sections.text:
Neat PANI tends to be brittle with poor ductility. PANI nanocomposite and resulting fibres have enhanced thermal and mechanical stability, as well as environmental constancy. For future energy and biotechnology applications, mechanically robust and free-standing PANI nanofibres must be explored. PANI nanofibres of blend and nanocomposite are smart materials for variety of applications such as sensor, supercapacitor, solar cell devices, and tissue engineering [84,85]. PANI nanofibre has been extensively pursued for feasible optical, electrical, chemical, and redox properties. Nevertheless, due to semirigid conformation and strong aggregation tendency, it may cause poor solubility in common solvents. Conceptually, new synthetic PANI nanocomposite nanofibres need to be developed with better quality, small diameter, and in large quantities. Issues of nanocomposite nanofibre processability and large-scale processing also need to be focused. Effect of
nanofibrillar morphology on the properties of PANI nanocomposite needs to be explored on advanced level. Future research must focus on faster and highly responsive sensors based on PANI/inorganic nanoparticle nanocomposite. Supercapacitor electrodes based on PANI nanocomposite fibre structure may also lead to new technological inventions. In this regard, PANI nanofibre with nanocarbon may lead to enhanced specific capacitance and power density of electrode materials. Future investigations must also emphasise functional PANI nanofibre-based solar cell technology. Use of conducting polymer blends may be useful to enhance the anticorrosion aspects of PANI nanomaterials. Dispersion of epoxy-coated PANI nanofibre in resins may also enhance the corrosion protection of these coatings. Moreover, PANI nanocomposite-based biodegradable scaffolds may brought about advances in tissue regeneration technology. Anti-microbial aspects of these materials may be enhanced using appropriate nanofiller reinforcement in PANI nanofibre.
PANI nanomaterials such as nanorod, nanotube, nanowire, and nanofibre have gained significant interest. PANI nanocomposite fibre has revealed tunable porosity, surface area, electrical and physical properties. PANI nanofibres have been prepared using electrospinning, nanolithography, self-assembly, template, and several chemical and physical methods. By manipulation of fabrication methods and parameters, nanofibre with desired properties and particular application can be achieved. Surface modification of nanofibre and PANI structure may also lead to high-performance materials. Applications of PANI nanocomposite nanofibre have been found in membranes, anticorrosion, solar cell, supercapacitor, sensor, and biomedical.
Disclosure statement
No potential conflict of interest was reported by the author.
Notes on contributor
Ayesha Kausar works at National University of Sciences and Technology, Islamabad, Pakistan. She has also worked for National Centre for Physics and Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan. She obtained her PhD from Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad/ KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science & Technology), Graduate School of EEWS, Daejeon, Republic of Korea. Her research interests include: synthesis, characterization and structure-property relationships of new polymeric materials; synthesis of nanomaterials including organic–inorganic nanocomposites/hybrid materials; polymeric blends via incorporating nanoparticles into thin polymer films; exploring practical and potential prospects of the novel synthesized materials (new polymers and nanomaterials) counting morphological, mechanical, thermal, electrical, conducting, etc.; flame retardant materials; proton conducting fuel cell membranes; nanocomposites for polymer Li-ion battery electrodes; composites based on electrospun nanofibers; production of various polymeric nanoparticles and their composites for solar cells; polymer/carbon nanotube/nanoparticle composites for water treatment; potential of polymer/graphite nanocomposites; polymer/graphene hybrids; polymer/fullerene nanomaterials; fabrication of epoxy-based nanocomposite for various applications; radar absorbing materials; aerospace relevance, and other technical relevances.

metadata.abstractText: Polyaniline (PANI) is one of the important types of intrinsically conducting polymers. Processability of PANI is daunting due to high level of conjugation and rigid backbone. PANI-based nanomaterials have been identified as new materials for rapidly growing technologies. Owing to enhanced and exceptional nanostructural characteristics, PANI-based nanomaterials have gained research curiosity. Thus, challenges faced in processing of neat PANI have led to the growth of PANI-based nanomaterials. This article presents development of PANI-based nanomaterials, their potential prospects in various technological fields, and future direction. Potential of PANI-based nanomaterials has been analysed in membranes, anticorrosion, solar cell, supercapacitor, sensor, and biomedical. ARTICLE HISTORY Received 2 March 2019 Accepted 17 April 2019
